question.title: How does log4j clean up actually works in hive metastore?
question.body:
I am trying to configure logs for hive metastore. I use this config:

status = INFO
name = HiveLog4j2
packages = org.apache.hadoop.hive.ql.log

property.hive.log.level = INFO
property.hive.root.logger = DRFA
property.hive.log.dir = ${sys:java.io.tmpdir}/${sys:user.name}
property.hive.log.file = hive.log
property.hive.perflogger.log.level = INFO

appenders = console, DRFA

appender.console.type = Console
appender.console.name = console
appender.console.target = SYSTEM_ERR
appender.console.layout.type = PatternLayout
appender.console.layout.pattern = %d{ISO8601} %5p [%t] %c{2}: %m%n

appender.DRFA.type = RollingRandomAccessFile
appender.DRFA.name = DRFA
appender.DRFA.fileName = ${sys:hive.log.dir}/${sys:hive.log.file}
appender.DRFA.filePattern = ${sys:hive.log.dir}/${sys:hive.log.file}.%d{yyyy-MM-dd-hh-mm}
appender.DRFA.layout.type = PatternLayout
appender.DRFA.layout.pattern = %d{ISO8601} %5p [%t] %c{2}: %m%n
appender.DRFA.policies.type = Policies
appender.DRFA.policies.time.type = SizeBasedTriggeringPolicy
appender.DRFA.policies.time.size = 4Kb
appender.DRFA.strategy.type = DefaultRolloverStrategy
appender.DRFA.strategy.max = 3

appender.DRFA.strategy.fileIndex = nomax
appender.DRFA.strategy.action.type = Delete
appender.DRFA.strategy.action.basepath =  ${sys:hive.log.dir}
appender.DRFA.strategy.action.condition.type = IfFileName
appender.DRFA.strategy.action.condition.glob = ${sys:hive.log.file}*
appender.DRFA.strategy.action.condition.ifAny.type = IfAny
appender.DRFA.strategy.action.condition.ifAny.ifAccumulatedFileSize.type = IfAccumulatedFileSize
appender.DRFA.strategy.action.condition.ifAny.ifAccumulatedFileSize.exceeds = 30Kb

# list of all loggers
loggers = NIOServerCnxn, ClientCnxnSocketNIO, DataNucleus, Datastore, JPOX, PerfLogger, AmazonAws, ApacheHttp
logger.NIOServerCnxn.name = org.apache.zookeeper.server.NIOServerCnxn
logger.NIOServerCnxn.level = WARN
logger.ClientCnxnSocketNIO.name = org.apache.zookeeper.ClientCnxnSocketNIO
logger.ClientCnxnSocketNIO.level = WARN
logger.DataNucleus.name = DataNucleus
logger.DataNucleus.level = ERROR
logger.Datastore.name = Datastore
logger.Datastore.level = ERROR
logger.JPOX.name = JPOX
logger.JPOX.level = ERROR
logger.AmazonAws.name=com.amazonaws
logger.AmazonAws.level = INFO
logger.ApacheHttp.name=org.apache.http
logger.ApacheHttp.level = INFO
logger.PerfLogger.name = org.apache.hadoop.hive.ql.log.PerfLogger
logger.PerfLogger.level = ${sys:hive.perflogger.log.level}
# root logger
rootLogger.level = ${sys:hive.log.level}
rootLogger.appenderRefs = root
rootLogger.appenderRef.root.ref = ${sys:hive.root.logger}

So it should:

- rolling logs every minute
- keep log files size `4Kb`
- keep only 3 logs files
- clean up old log files when entire folder grows more than `30Kb`

What it actually does: - there much more than 3 logs - all files are truncated to 8Kb - folder size much more than 30Kb - some files like hive.log.2025-06-26-06-25 and hive.log.2025-06-26-06-26 were deleted with 5 and 10 minutes lag

May be my setting are too small and there is a delay for logs cleanup? Any thoughts?

Here is file size log (last file is minute when du invocated):

hive@hive-metastore:/opt/hive$  du -hs /tmp/hive/*
4.0K    /tmp/hive/hive.log
28K     /tmp/hive/hive.log.2025-06-26-06-25
hive@hive-metastore:/opt/hive$  du -hs /tmp/hive/*
4.0K    /tmp/hive/hive.log
12K     /tmp/hive/hive.log.2025-06-26-06-25
hive@hive-metastore:/opt/hive$  du -hs /tmp/hive/*

12K     /tmp/hive/hive.log.2025-06-26-06-25
8.0K    /tmp/hive/hive.log.2025-06-26-06-26

answers.body:
The log behavior you're seeing aligns with how your Log4j2 configuration is currently set up.

Current configuration file

Let me break down the key points of the way you configured your RollingRandomAccessFile.

1. Rolling based on file size only

You're using SizeBasedTriggeringPolicy, which rolls the log file when it exceeds a specified size (in your case, 4 KiB).

To roll files every minute, you'd also need to include a TimeBasedTriggeringPolicy.

2. 4 KiB limit applies to the active file only

The 4 KiB size limit is enforced only on the currently active log file. Once it exceeds that limit, the file is rolled over. However, the archived files will be slightly larger than 4 KiB due to the triggering point being after the threshold is crossed.

For example, if a log line causes the file to grow from 3.9 KiB to 4.1 KiB, it gets rolled over—but the archived file will still be 4.1 KiB (or more).
This also explains why du -h reports 8 KiB per rolled file: the actual size is slightly over 4 KiB, and it gets rounded up to the next 4 KiB block.

3. Only the rolling index is limited by max

This is a common point of confusion: the max attribute in DefaultRolloverStrategy limits only the number of rolled files per %d timestamp, by limiting the value of the %i placeholder. It does not limit the total number of archived log files globally.

This means that for each unique value of the %d{yyyy-MM-dd-HH-mm} timestamp (e.g., 2025-06-26-06-25), up to max indexed files will be retained. The way rollover files are managed depends on the fileIndex strategy (min, max). If you set the strategy to noMax this limit is ignored! See Incrementing file indexes for more details.

For example, if your pattern is hive.log.%d{yyyy-MM-dd-HH-mm}.%i and you're using fileIndex="max" with max="3", then within a single minute, Log4j2 might retain:

hive.log.2025-06-26-06-25.1  
hive.log.2025-06-26-06-25.2  
hive.log.2025-06-26-06-25.3

When the next rollover happens, the oldest file (.1) is deleted, the remaining two rotated and a new .3 file is created.

In your case, you're not using %i in the pattern. This makes the behavior even simpler: every rollover overwrites the file for that minute. Only one archived file per minute is retained.

4. Total size cap

The log cleaner kicks in when the total size of files matching hive.log* exceeds 30 KiB, per your configuration. This is consistent with what you're observing: once the cumulative size passes that threshold, older files are deleted to bring usage back under control.

Note: Only files that match the filePattern are counted toward this size limit. Other unrelated files in the directory are ignored.

Alternative Configuration

The behavior you're aiming for can be achieved using the XML configuration snippet below. This configuration accomplishes the following:

  • Rolls log files every minute or when they exceed 4 KiB, whichever comes first.
  • Keeps each archived log file just above 4 KiB (the configured threshold plus the size of the final log event).
  • Limits the total number of archived files to 3, regardless of timestamp or index.
<!-- 1. Add `%i` to allow multiple rolled files per minute -->
<RollingRandomAccessFile name="DRFA"
                         fileName="${sys:hive.log.dir}/${sys:hive.log.file}"
                         filePattern="${sys:hive.log.dir}/${sys:hive.log.file}.%d{yyyy-MM-dd-HH-mm}.%i">
  <PatternLayout pattern="%d{ISO8601} %5p [%t] %c{2}: %m%n"/>
  
  <DefaultRolloverStrategy fileIndex="nomax">
    <!-- 2. Limit total number of archived log files -->
    <Delete basePath="${sys:hive.log.dir}">
      <IfFileName glob="${sys:hive.log.file}.*">
        <IfAccumulatedFileCount exceeds="3"/>
      </IfFileName>
    </Delete>
  </DefaultRolloverStrategy>
  
  <Policies>
    <!-- 3. Trigger on file size -->
    <SizeBasedTriggeringPolicy size="4 KB"/>
    <!-- 4. Also trigger every minute -->
    <TimeBasedTriggeringPolicy/>
  </Policies>
</RollingRandomAccessFile>

Note: While Log4j 2 Core does support the Java Properties format, it has several drawbacks: its syntax is inconsistent with other formats (XML, JSON, YAML), it tends to be more verbose, and it includes numerous exceptions to its own syntax rules. These quirks can lead to confusion and subtle misconfigurations. For clarity, consistency, and maintainability—especially in non-trivial configurations—we recommend any other format, like the XML in the example.

question_comments.body: Note that du reports the disk usage of files, not their size. Since most filesystems use 4 KiB blocks, all the results you have will be multiples of 4 KiB. Use ls -h to see the size of the files.
